comments.commentBody:
Torn between 2 Phones: Nexus One vs. iPhone
My personal knowledge and experience with these phones is somewhat limited. However, I have discovered some interesting features about the Nexus One Cellular phone that I would like to investigate further:

3.7 inch high Amoled display micro SD card slot with 16.7 million colors and 800x480 pixel resolution
Linux 2.1 operating system with a wider variety of applications programming capabilities in JAVA
Very fast with 1 GHZ mobile processor with 600 MHZ CPU and DROID clocks in at 530 MHZ
512 MB of RAM
512 MB of ROM
Good voice input
Battery shelf life of 7.8 hour battery life
With the exception of AT&T, Nexus One supports 3G globally
Supports HSDA for high speed performance on both uploading and downloading
Sim card capability to use on most GSM mobile devices.
Chrome web browser capabilities for rendering HTML-pages and JavaScript
Faster and Flexible web browsing capabilities wider range of searching

The phone features seem to be impressive, however, there are problems for Google with public security. This is largely due to the iPhone Safari’s internet browser feature, which has a dial phone number that is easily accessible by hackers. Hackers have the capability of taking over all calls incoming in and going out. They can obtain the phone numbers and use the numbers in dangerous ways. Google also has a problem with its wide range web browsing service. This service requires monitoring security levels and auditability to meet compliance requirements.

To suggest a strategy for Google I would recommend referencing the server side of applications. For example, Cloud computing uses the Android operating system, with a high-speed network connection to communicate with a clone of itself and resides in the cloud-computing environment. Android is used to maximize what the server architect and programmers can do on a small client machine. It preserves battery power because in the server environment, Android is hooked into a power grid, which allows for a lot of software access from the grid.

I guess more dots does not necessarily mean better. I like the suggestion of replacing dots with a variable bar to indicate the amount.

Also, I notice that this chart is geek centric in that it does not have a row for the intangible "design" to indicate the over-all experience in Job's sense of the world "design" which is a so very important ingredient for Apple. It's almost a separate thing.
So what is the point of this trivia? If this is news, then what is next ... the first tweet from the bathroom?

Land tours are becoming good options in the Galapagos for people wanting to not spend so much time at sea traveling between islands and feeling stuck on a ship.  Adventure Life Journeys has a few active land-based trips, and I have stayed in Puerto Ayora doing day trips.

I turned it off at halftime.  I was eager to watch to see some of the experimental players.  I knew the US wasn't going to field a top team.  That's what these games are for.  So I am at a loss to see why the ref saw it necessary to toss Conrad.  Tossing a man, on either team, so early on in the game made it impossible to fully run "the experiment".  Let 11 men run out there, throw in a few subs, see who has a spark.  But playing with ten makes it a completely different game, and a different mission.  Now you're just trying to hang on.  What a waste.  Nothing was learned.  A waste of a match when we need them.

Revealingly awful performance by the US tonight. Granted, it was only a friendly but we were at home and WC spots were theoretically on the line. Shocking lack of passion and cohesion from our Nats, even factoring in the rash red card.

I love Feilhaber's technique but his intensity is lacking. Poor showing tonight.
Wynne? Project for 2014 at best...someone please teach that kid positioning & crossing!
Goodson showed his class again ; the guy has done the job each time he's been called up over the last 12 months. BB should start him over Bocanegra.
Bedoya is intriguing. I like his chances for 2014.

Finally, I'm not a fan of summarily writing off a player's international career (as many have unwisely done for Beasley and Eddie Johnson) but I'll make an exception for Jimmy Conrad. He's the poster boy for US fans who worship "charlie hustle" players over actual talent; "he's a leader, he's soo crafty, he gives good interview".... well he's just too old/slow to get it done anymore, if he ever did. Conrad's starting slot should have been given Omar Gonzales or Geoff Cameron, even Brandon McDonald. At least then we would have learned something we didn't already know.

comments.commentBody: Can someone please check on Rich in Atlanta... this isn't like him to miss out on a Favruh serenade.

This goes out to PM-  You are absolutely right, some of us do live in a fantasy world, but the thing is, some fantasies come true, like it did 41 yrs. ago. While it's true that Sanchez is no Joe Willie, he's probably not going to HAVE to be. Here's one more thing: The REALLY GREAT thing about football is that no matter how much better a team is on paper, which the colts clearly are just by virtue of games won, they still have to PLAY THE GAME ! There is an old adage in football, it goes- On any given Sunday........(any posters care to finish the phrase?)

Rich,

After what happened last year, he can't be allowed to beat us.

And though I hold no animosity toward him, I do hold him accountable. He should have pulled himself out of the lineup last year. He knew his injury was the problem.

In actuality I'm grateful how it all turned out.

But yeah I'd like to see him on his back instead of doing what he wants.

Above all, this seemed a wasted opportunity (Thank you, Mr. Conrad). I have no idea how Bradley goes about evaluating anyone here, except in a player's response to being broken against, repeatedly.

However, if you're looking to find an alternate up front, why not start Casey as the target and try out Findley, then Cunningham, off of him? Or were we supposed to see blazing runs and pinpoint passing from these, um, midfielders?

Beckerman rolls a ball 12 feet as well as anyone in the game today. Someone should tell him that running into space is a good thing. Unless, of course, possession isn't part of the strategy.

Many of these same questions came to my mind immediately upon viewing the photos of the disaster published by the Times. While clicking through the images in the slideshow I began to ask myself, "Is this too much? Would the individuals depicted want me to see them in these circumstances? Has anyone asked permission to take these photos?"

Then, just at that moment, my seven-year-old daughter walked up beside me and began staring at the computer screen. I had already attempted to explain to her about the earthquake, as well as about the prior conditions in Haiti, but, as we do not have television, she had not yet seen any images of the disaster. So, at that point, I sat down with her, and we spent the next hour looking at the photos and talking about them. It was this experience, I think, which enabled her to process and completely comprehend all that I had been telling her.

In this sense, I feel that these photographs, and particularly the larger photo essay, are an invaluable tool of understanding, and not at all sensationalist. If the real horrors had not been shown, if the more gruesome or heart-wrenching photos had been edited out, the truth would not have been accurately depicted. Yes, no doubt, visual images - especially such graphic images as these - are far more evocative of intense emotions than are mere words. But I think that, particularly in a situation such as this, we have to ask ourselves if it is really just that we should ask to be "spared" the gruesome and horrific details. Perhaps there is also a just concern that in depicting the suffering and death of these individuals the Times is somehow robbing them of their basic human dignity. But my question is this: Which is more dignified - to suffer and die and to have one's suffering and death go undocumented and therefore unacknowledged by the masses, or to suffer and die and it be documented so that it might serve to bring awareness to the masses? There is no human dignity in suffering and death that goes unnoticed.

It is easy to point fingers at the Times and their reporters and editors when a few mistakes or omissions are made. We can see that here. Stories are not like working with numbers and prices, they often go in a direction not anticipated and that can change the questions you ask. Each story is different.

Thanks for the piece.
having nodded off about 5 times i got up and turned off the set
lol what's next?  automatic speeding ticket through monitoring of your in car navigation system?

The picture really spoke to me - A true all terrain vehicle that doesn't pretend to be a real car, quiet like a hippo, red like a sled. Plus I want to use that first date line: Oh dear we're out of electricity - should we swim or just wait for the moon to rise?

Then I read the price $30k and it has lead acid batteries instead of Lithium Ion batteries. There aren't enough meds to make me think this is a good deal.

Better off buying a new Prius and a kayak and use the left over money to buy a subscription to Mother Earth Magazine.

The majority of people are taking the Colts to kill the Jets this
week but you have to consider how well New York matches up against
Indy. Indy has the worst running game in the league, and is ALL
Peyton. The Jets have the #1 pass-defence and if they can put the
clamps on Peyton early… it could very well be a Jets win. TheCoach
isn’t calling a J-E-T-S JETS JETS JETS win but they will cover the
spread. I know Indy shut down Baltimore’s running game last week
but the Jets strive on being quick and elusive.. something Ray Rice
isn’t…

Minnesota and New Orleans is going to be such a good game. I was
hoping all season long these two would meet up in the NFC
Championship and honestly.. either team could team this game. The
Saints are -3.0 favourites and historically home team get given three
points for the home-field advantage… so basically this game is a
pick-em and there is ONE thing that I like about the Saints and its
that home-field advantage. Last week Warner and Romo combined for 7
sacks and 4 fumbles largely in part to not being able to communicate
with their offence. The SuperDome is NUTS and I don’t care how much
experience Favre has, the crowd can help a team and also hurt the
other so much.

Feel free to check out my picks with scores (and of course
cheerleader pictures) @
http://www.lionsdenu.com...

Best of luck to all this week,
Regards,
TheCoach

There has to be a limited market for motorcycles that are poorly engineered, overweight and sluggish to handle.  Hardly Davidson has probably reached the edges of selling into this market and now must figure out how to manufacture and sell a better bike with aging technology and poor quality control or they need to reinvent themselves completely.
Q. So, Shonne Green: Better then Thomas Jones or A LOT better then Thomas Jones?

Can someone explain 13 down to me?  Is "Saves" a legitimate definition for "STAT".  I had "STET" (editing-speak for retain) and "PANATELLE" which is a valid alternative spelling for PANATELLA, but this was evidently incorrect - at least Across Lite says it is.  All I can utter is a response of confusion, "EH"?

So Prince is watching the Vikings games from his box in the Metrodome and the intensity and passion the Vikings team he roots for inspired this song? Are we sure he wasn't watching an episode of "Property Virgins" on HGTV and was caught up in the real estate process?

I mean, this can't be a result of actual football watching.
The envelope has been pushed.
Conventional WWII-era submarines indeed did run on lead-acid batteries but, when these batteries got wet, the submarines could easily became toxic coffins.
